query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 O poca nostra nobiltà di sangue, 2 se glorïar di te la gente fai 3 qua giù dove l’affetto nostro langue,
4 mirabil cosa non mi sarà mai: 5 ché là dove appetito non si torce, 6 dico nel cielo, io me ne gloriai.
query.result:
1 O little our nobility of blood, 2 if to glorify of you the people do, 3 here down where our affection languishes,
4 marvelous thing will never be to me: 5 because there where appetite does not twist, 6 I say in the sky, I gloried myself.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
7 Ben se’ tu manto che tosto raccorce: 8 sì che, se non s’appon di dì in die, 9 lo tempo va dintorno con le force.
query.result: 7 Well you are a mantle that quickly shortens: 8 so that, if it does not happen day by day, 9 time goes around with the forces.

10 From the “you” that first in Rome was offended, 11 in which his family less persisted, 12 my words began again;
13 whereby Beatrice, who was a little scevra, 14 laughing, seemed that one who tossio 15 at the first fault written of Geneva.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
19 Per tanti rivi s’empie d’allegrezza 20 la mente mia, che di sé fa letizia 21 perché può sostener che non si spezza.
query.result: 19 Through many streams it fills with cheerfulness 20 my mind, which makes joy of itself 21 because it can sustain that it does not break.

22 Tell me then, my dear primizia, 23 what were your ancients and what were the years 24 that were marked in your purity;
25 tell me of the ovil of Saint John 26 how much it was then, and who were the peoples 27 among them worthy of higher skins».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Come s’avviva a lo spirar d’i venti 29 carbone in fiamma, così vid’ io quella 30 luce risplendere a’ miei blandimenti;
31 e come a li occhi miei si fé più bella, 32 così con voce più dolce e soave, 33 ma non con questa moderna favella,
34 dissemi: «Da quel dì che fu detto ‘Ave’ 35 al parto in che mia madre, ch’è or santa, 36 s’allevïò di me ond’ era grave,
37 al suo Leon cinquecento cinquanta 38 e trenta fiate venne questo foco 39 a rinfiammarsi sotto la sua pianta.
query.result:
28 How it becomes alive to the breathing of the winds 29 carbon in flame, so I saw that 30 light shining on my flattery;
31 and as to my eyes it became more beautiful, 32 so with voice more sweet and gentle, 33 but not with this modern speech,
34 he said to me: “From that day that was said ‘Ave’ 35 at the birth in which my mother, who is now holy, 36 was raised of me where it was heavy,
37 to his Leon five hundred fifty 38 and thirty times this fire came 39 to reignite under its plant.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 Li antichi miei e io nacqui nel loco 41 dove si truova pria l’ultimo sesto 42 da quei che corre il vostro annüal gioco.
query.result: 40 My ancient ones and I was born in the place 41 where the last sixth is first found 42 by those who run your annual game

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
43 Basti d’i miei maggiori udirne questo: 44 chi ei si fosser e onde venner quivi, 45 più è tacer che ragionare onesto.
query.result: 43 It is enough, from my superiors, to hear this: 44 who he might be and from where he came here, 45 it is more to be silent than to reason honestly.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
46 Tutti color ch’a quel tempo eran ivi 47 da poter arme tra Marte e ’l Batista, 48 eran il quinto di quei ch’or son vivi.
query.result: 46 All those who at that time were there 47 to be able to arm themselves between Mars and the Baptist, 48 were the fifth of those who now are alive.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Ma la cittadinanza, ch’è or mista 50 di Campi, di Certaldo e di Fegghine, 51 pura vediesi ne l’ultimo artista.
query.result: 49 But the citizenship, which is now mixed 50 of Campi, of Certaldo and of Fegghine, 51 purely would be seen in the last artist.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 Oh quanto fora meglio esser vicine 53 quelle genti ch’io dico, e al Galluzzo 54 e a Trespiano aver vostro confine,
55 che averle dentro e sostener lo puzzo 56 del villan d’Aguglion, di quel da Signa, 57 che già per barattare ha l’occhio aguzzo!
58 Se la gente ch’al mondo più traligna 59 non fosse stata a Cesare noverca, 60 ma come madre a suo figlio benigna,
61 tal fatto è fiorentino e cambia e merca, 62 che si sarebbe vòlto a Simifonti, 63 là dove andava l’avolo a la cerca;
64 sariesi Montemurlo ancor de’ Conti; 65 sarieno i Cerchi nel piovier d’Acone, 66 e forse in Valdigrieve i Buondelmonti.
query.result:
52 Oh how much would be better to be near 53 those peoples that I speak of, and to Galluzzo 54 and to Trespiano have your border,
55 that to have them inside and sustain the stench 56 of the peasant of Aguglion, of that from Signa, 57 who already for bartering has a sharp eye!
58 If the people who betray the world the most 59 were not a newcomer to Caesar, 60 but like a mother to her son benevolent,
61 such a deed is Florentine and changes and trades, 62 that it would have turned to Simifonti, 63 there where the avolo went to the search;
64 it would be Montemurlo still of the Counts; 65 the Cerchi would be in the pigeonhole of Acone, 66 and perhaps in Valdigrieve the Buondelmonti.

67 Always the confusion of the people 68 principle was of the evil of the city, 69 as of yours the food that is placed;
70 and blind bull more avaccio falls 71 than blind lamb; and many times cuts 72 more and better one than the five swords.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
73 Se tu riguardi Luni e Orbisaglia 74 come sono ite, e come se ne vanno 75 di retro ad esse Chiusi e Sinigaglia,
76 udir come le schiatte si disfanno 77 non ti parrà nova cosa né forte, 78 poscia che le cittadi termine hanno.
query.result:
73 If you look at Luni and Orbisaglia 74 how they have gone, and how they go away 75 from behind them Chiusi and Sinigaglia,
76 to hear how the schiatte fall apart 77 it will not seem a new thing nor strong to you, 78 after that the cities have an end.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
79 Le vostre cose tutte hanno lor morte, 80 sì come voi; ma celasi in alcuna 81 che dura molto, e le vite son corte.
query.result: 79 Your things all have their death, 80 as you; but hidden in some 81 that lasts a long time, and the lives are short.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
82 E come ’l volger del ciel de la luna 83 cuopre e discuopre i liti sanza posa, 84 così fa di Fiorenza la Fortuna:
85 per che non dee parer mirabil cosa 86 ciò ch’io dirò de li alti Fiorentini 87 onde è la fama nel tempo nascosa.
query.result:
82 And as the turning of the sky of the moon 83 covers and uncovers the liti without pause, 84 so does Fortune of Florence:
85 for which it should not seem a marvelous thing 86 that which I will say of the high Florentines 87 where the fame is hidden in time.

88 I saw the Ughi and I saw the Catellini, 89 Filippi, Greci, Ormanni and Alberichi, 90 already in the decline, illustrious citizens;
91 and I saw so great as ancient, 92 with that of the Sannella, that of the Ark, 93 and Soldanieri and Ardinghi and Bostichi.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 Sovra la porta ch’al presente è carca 95 di nova fellonia di tanto peso 96 che tosto fia iattura de la barca,
97 erano i Ravignani, ond’ è disceso 98 il conte Guido e qualunque del nome 99 de l’alto Bellincione ha poscia preso.
query.result:
94 Above the gate which at present is loaded 95 with new felony of such weight 96 that soon will be the jettison of the boat,
97 were the Ravignani, where has descended 98 Count Guido and whoever of the name 99 of the high Bellincione has afterwards taken.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
100 Quel de la Pressa sapeva già come 101 regger si vuole, e avea Galigaio 102 dorata in casa sua già l’elsa e ’l pome.
query.result: 100 That of the Pressa already knew how 101 to hold it is wanted, and had Galigaio 102 golden in his house already the elsa and the pome

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
103 Grand’ era già la colonna del Vaio, 104 Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti e Barucci 105 e Galli e quei ch’arrossan per lo staio.
query.result: 103 Great was already the column of the Vaio, 104 Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti and Barucci 105 and Galli and those who blush through the staio.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 Lo ceppo di che nacquero i Calfucci 107 era già grande, e già eran tratti 108 a le curule Sizii e Arrigucci.
query.result: 106 The stock from which the Calfucci were born 107 was already large, and already were drawn 108 to the curule Sizii and Arrigucci

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 Oh quali io vidi quei che son disfatti 110 per lor superbia! e le palle de l’oro 111 fiorian Fiorenza in tutt’ i suoi gran fatti.
query.result: 109 Oh what I saw those who are undone 110 for their pride! and the balls of gold 111 flourish Florence in all its great deeds

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
112 Così facieno i padri di coloro 113 che, sempre che la vostra chiesa vaca, 114 si fanno grassi stando a consistoro.
query.result: 112 Thus did the fathers of those 113 who, whenever your church is empty, 114 they become fat staying at the consistoro

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
115 L’oltracotata schiatta che s’indraca 116 dietro a chi fugge, e a chi mostra ’l dente 117 o ver la borsa, com’ agnel si placa,
118 già venìa sù, ma di picciola gente; 119 sì che non piacque ad Ubertin Donato 120 che poï il suocero il fé lor parente.
query.result:
115 The overcrowned schiatta that twists 116 behind to the one who flees, and to the one who shows the tooth 117 or to the purse, as a lamb is appeased
118 already rose up, but of a small people; 119 so that it did not please Ubertin Donato 120 that later the father‑in‑law made him their relative.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Già era ’l Caponsacco nel mercato 122 disceso giù da Fiesole, e già era 123 buon cittadino Giuda e Infangato.
query.result: 121 Already was the Caponsacco in the market 122 descended down from Fiesole, and already was 123 good citizen Giuda and Infangato.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
124 Io dirò cosa incredibile e vera: 125 nel picciol cerchio s’entrava per porta 126 che si nomava da quei de la Pera.
query.result: 124 I will say what incredible and true: 125 in the little circle one entered through door 126 that was named by those of the Pera.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 Ciascun che de la bella insegna porta 128 del gran barone il cui nome e ’l cui pregio 129 la festa di Tommaso riconforta,
130 da esso ebbe milizia e privilegio; 131 avvegna che con popol si rauni 132 oggi colui che la fascia col fregio.
query.result:
127 Each one who of the beautiful ensign carries 128 of the great baron whose name and whose worth 129 the feast of Thomas comforts,
130 from him had militia and privilege; 131 it happens that with people he/she/it unites 132 today he who the band with the emblem.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
133 Già eran Gualterotti e Importuni; 134 e ancor saria Borgo più quïeto, 135 se di novi vicin fosser digiuni.

Please translate each line literally into English.
136 La casa di che nacque il vostro fleto, 137 per lo giusto disdegno che v’ha morti 138 e puose fine al vostro viver lieto,
139 era onorata, essa e suoi consorti: 140 o Buondelmonte, quanto mal fuggisti 141 le nozze süe per li altrui conforti!
142 Molti sarebber lieti, che son tristi, 143 se Dio t’avesse conceduto ad Ema 144 la prima volta ch’a città venisti.
query.result:
136 The house of which was born your lament, 137 for the just disdain that has killed you 138 and put an end to your happy life,
139 it was honored, she and her consorts: 140 O Buondelmonte, how badly you fled 141 his weddings for the comforts of others!
142 Many would be happy, who are sad, 143 if God had granted you to Ema 144 the first time that you came to the city.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
145 Ma conveniesi a quella pietra scema 146 che guarda ’l ponte, che Fiorenza fesse 147 vittima ne la sua pace postrema.
query.result: 145 But it suited that barren stone 146 that looks at the bridge, which Florence made 147 victim in its final peace

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
148 Con queste genti, e con altre con esse, 149 vid’ io Fiorenza in sì fatto riposo, 150 che non avea cagione onde piangesse.
query.result: 148 With these peoples, and with others with them, 149 I saw Florence in such made rest, 150 that it had no cause whereby it might weep.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
151 Con queste genti vid’io glorïoso 152 e giusto il popol suo, tanto che ’l giglio 153 non era ad asta mai posto a ritroso,
154 né per divisïon fatto vermiglio».
query.result:
151 With these peoples I saw glorious 152 and just his people, so that the lily 153 was never on a stake placed backward,
154 nor by division made vermilion.
